subject: Add erase sanitize
commitMessage:
Add erase sanitize

Sanitize uses the eMMC firmware to erase all blocks.

Tested:
$ cat /dev/urandom > /dev/mmcblk0

$ time busctl call xyz.openbmc_project.eStoraged.mmcblk0 \
/xyz/openbmc_project/inventory/storage/mmcblk0 \
xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item.Volume Erase s \
xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item.Volume.EraseMethod.VendorSanitize \
--timeout=1200

real    0m1.793s
user    0m0.021s
sys     0m0.009s

root@ytbaz20-nfd01:/# cat /dev/mmcblk0 | hexdump

0000000 0000 0000 0000 0000 0000 0000 0000 0000
*

Signed-off-by: John Edward Broadbent <jebr@google.com>
Change-Id: I31bc21c0b6d31cbba0db752d94a93eb004dbbde6

Let's include this in the prior CL since these are required from the start (missed on the first review)
If this is supposed to be an interface class, would prefer all methods be pure virtual

Santize provides a base class for SanitizeImpl and mockSanitize. Both inherited classes can use the same doSanitize method. But they have different wrapperIOCTL methods.
This allows for testing. 

Let me know if you have a different design in mind.

Ah yes, similar to the suggestion I gave to John Wedig for the other CL - the wrapper should be a separate class that you pass to Sanitize here as an interface (and you can mock the wrapper).

https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/estoraged/+/48972 - please take a look at how eStoraged and filesystemInterface is structured.

How I imagine this would be designed and tested would be - Sanitize is no longer an interface + implementation class (we could, if you think you'll need to mock the Sanitize class in the future) and we'll have IOCTL as an interface + implementation class. That way, in your test you'll create the actual Sanitize class but pass in the mock IOCTL wrapper.

In this case since it's only a single API, it does feel like a bit of an overkill.. so I'm open to other suggestions / opinions.

This is a inheritance vs composition question. I was mocking using inheritance to override the ioctl member function. I just just switch to having a ioctl object owned by sanitize (composition), that can be mocked. 
 
I don't have a strong preference
Are we going to implement anything specific in the Sanitize destructor? I don't think we need this if the base class declares the destructor virtual default
If an interface class (and thus pure virutal), we shouldn't have private class, perhaps you meant protected here?
minor nit: prefer "Impl" for "Implementation" - I'm guess this that's what this is?
IWYU, need to include string, and string_view includes
stylistic nit: prefer having the constructor declared in the header
question: is this needed? If they should always start with 0s, maybe we should set the struct members to all be set to 0 in struct declaration?

The struct has 16 elements in it, and ideally if new fields are added I don't want to have to update this code. 

Maybe initializing the struct to default ( ={}) will be more clear. Let me know if you would prefer the longer explicit initialization for each field, and I will switch to it.

Yup, this is cleaner.

When I suggested setting the struct members to 0 in struct declaration, I meant in declaration of the struct - but just realized mmc_ioc_cmd is not something we can touch. This looks good now.
it should be info. thanks for the catch
stylistic nit: prefer having the constructor declared in the header

Seems like we already have the test meson.build one directory up - should we just include "sanitize" to the existing meson instead?

Otherwise, you could use subdirectory and append to tests in each subdirectories if you prefer.

Edit: Looking below, seems like you added it already? I think we can delete this then right?
yep, this was a merge based oversight on my part

Should we have more test coverages?

Could we be a little more descriptive in the test? or add a comment for test description.
let me know if you think I need more cases

is that the same as putting as MockSanitize goodSanitize("/dev/null"); ?

done
Oh yeah, that's probably better. since we don't have to declare a variable we won't use besides the initialization here.
Same here and below, we should probably just declare the string inplace in the initialization
Maybe this parameter should be void *, so that you don't need 2 different wrappers? See what Brandon and William think.
I don't have strong feelings either way. Passing a void * make the interface weaker, but it would get rid of redundant code.
This is probably fine as-is. Earlier, I thought it was unnecessary to have 2 functions that do the same thing, but it's not a lot of code duplication.
I'm guessing you intend to remove these cerr prints at some point?
yep, but there this is still no working the way it should be.

It might make sense to create helper functions for each of the eMMC operations in this file, where you set up a command and then call the ioctl. For example, a helper function for the sanitize command and another for the erase command.

This is working now.
I had do do a work around for because the eMMC firmware does not appear to follow the spec.

Can you comment what this means?

Also, should this go in the .cpp file? That's the only place you're using it.
This code will never be reached since twiddleBrokenEXT_CSD_ERASE_GROUP_DEF is hard-coded to true.
yes, but it might be important if the eMMC is made spec complaint, or when we use working emmc.
nit: This comment is misleading. The test won't attempt to open the file, since doIoctlMulti() is mocked out.
Let me know if you see anything else

Do you intend for this to ultimately replace your hard-coded constant in the .cpp file? It's currently not used.

Also, I wonder if the purpose of this would be more clear if you called it something different, e.g. force_low_capacity_sanitize.

I do plan to have this setting as a build time option.
I changed it so it is being used now.
This is not internal to Google, so we probably shouldn't use language like "our eMMC".
The Samsung datasheet says this is 0 at power-up. I guess the driver might be setting this bit?
Strictly speaking, you should only be checking bit 0 in this register. The upper bits are reserved.
Can you get this value from a register? Where did you get 512?

This comes from the eMMC spec
Table 39, page 108 
Erase Group Size is 512B (only applies if EXT_CSD_ERASE_GROUP_DEF is 0)

Alright, thanks for the pointer. If I'm understanding correctly, we can read the NATIVE_SECTOR_SIZE register to determine this value. Is there a reason you're not doing that? It's either going to be 512B or 4KB (for large eMMCs).
It comes from 6.6.34 as I understand the spec
The fact that the build didn't fail on this naming issue would imply you guys didn't check in a clang-tidy?  Please do that post-haste, and clean up the errors before you check in any more features.
We enabled clang tidy, but it does not flag this. I am unsure why.
I don't think you should be setting this to 0. This might conflict with the driver in Linux, which is probably the thing setting this to 1.

From reading 6.6.9, my understanding is that this arg is specified as an address, not in erase blocks. Addresses are expressed either in bytes or 512 byte sectors. See section 5.2. This address isn't necessarily the same as erase blocks.

In light of this, I suspect the 'twiddle' stuff is unnecessary. IIUC the value of ERASE_GROUP_DEF hardly matters when you do an erase. It is only relevant in that the eMMC rounds down to the nearest erase group boundary.
okay, I changed the code to reflect this.
if we don't do this the erase does not work. I can't explain why in the spec we need to do this, but "it is what is "?
hmm, I guess the start and end addresses represent an inclusive range. For example, if we only wanted to erase the first block, the ERASE_GROUP_START would be 0, and ERASE_GROUP_END would also be 0.
Why does your commit message show the same busctl command twice?

I updated the busctl call with the new path.
I will remove the command that uses the old path.

Did you ever try reading the OCR register to determine which addressing scheme to use?

At the very least, if you want to leave this hard-coded to 512 bytes, you should probably add a comment saying this is only correct if the eMMC is >=2GB.
I don't think this is the right section. Section 5.2 talks about sector addresses.
I will update the comment. I think it is unlikely we will use a smaller eMMC.

In section 6.6.34
Table 39 — e•MMC internal sizes and related Units / Granularities
Defines the sector Native sector size 512.
Thanks Wedig for the thorough review - looks like they just need addressing with some of my comments before this can go in.
These are no longer necessary, right?

minor nit / question: I'm not sure what the proper rule for file scoped constants are - should they perhaps be placed in an anonymous namespace? I'm not sure what the best practice is actually. This is probably fine too.

Yeah, I can put them in an anonymous namespace. 
I could also add them to the class namespace, that might be a more normal approach, but the that would increase the scope.
The anonymous sounds like a good idea.

minor nit: The

Also, I guess the header has the doxygen styled detail already - so not sure if this is needed.

Typically there are not comments describing the function in the cpp file.
I will remove them to keep the code consistent.

Let me know if that is not okay

minor nit: The

Also, I guess the header has the doxygen styled detail already - so not sure if this is needed.

Typically there are not comments describing the function in the cpp file.
I will remove them to keep the code consistent.

Let me know if that is not okay
I update the comment, to be more clear (sanitize::emmcErase)

I think this test name is misleading. Something like EraseFailure might be better.

The fact that the file doesn't exist doesn't matter, since the ioctls get mocked out. This test is actually exercising the case where the erase ioctl fails.

The test is designed to exercise what would happen (in the sanitize logic) if the file was not found. (because that is likely to happen eventually) 

If the file is not found I expect
- IOCTL returns -1,
- and sanitize::emmcErase to throw

I will change the name to be more clear
